Actually we're not distributing the SW, we offer it as a hosted
service and=
 hold all software internally.  We do an accounting app
that tracks royalty=
 streams, the current market that we're working on
is the music industry wh=
ere we track royalty income payments to
artists from labels and other incom=
e sources and then split the money
within the band.  Abit like  hearding ca=
ts...  We're looking forward
to other licensee-licensor markets (books, toy=
s, IP, semiconductor,
clothings, etc) and hoping that they'll be abit more =
straightfwd.

With that said we are trying to position ourselves to get the=
 SW
middle/back end ready to license as an API, and if that ends up
happeni=
ng then I'd see value in providing a test suite for the backend
along with =
the API binaries.  We'd see doing this in order to allow
other programmers =
to view tests, experiment with params, see high and
low values, etc in orde=
r to help them come up to speed on our API. 
Provides customer confidence t=
hat API works as advertised  -- as well
as providing us a known good line i=
n the sand, so that if they
mis-impement the API we can point them back to =
the tests as a means of
establishing a baseline level of API functionality.=
  Helps keep us out
of finger pointing situations with misunderstandings ab=
out what
functinality the API provides.  

But right now we're (read: me) t=
rying to get a test suite together,
rather get it setup as "right" as I can=
 and avoid refactoring later

Enjoying the book, well written, working well=
 for me. Slow reading but
thats probably more of a pilot error on this end.=
..

Mike

ou either have
Java

t them in the

ture,
possibly 
> in a subdirectory with test in the name.
> 
> /jsp/market=
/app1/test/<test JSPs>
> /jsp/WEB-INF/classes/com/company/application/modul=
e/test/<test classes>
> 
> I'm curious, though: why are you shipping your t=
ests with your 
> application? I like the idea, but not many people do it. =
Why are you 
> doing it?
